Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class gave a decent overview of some common biology topics as well as a survey approach towards some more advanced ideas.

I learned the most important biochemical molecules and interactions that govern the cell. I learned how different molecules were discovered and the experiments used to discover structure and functions of biological molecules including nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates.
Reading/analyzing scientific papers
I learned to read and think critically about primary scientific literature.

I gained a better understanding of the cellular mechanisms and components involved in our everyday life from what causes cancer, to what makes us unique, to how we store energy, etc. I also gained a better understanding of the improvement in technologies used in biological research. This was extremely beneficial as I hope to develop these technologies in the future. This class prepared students interested in research as it not only introduced us to the mechanisms behind lab equipment but also taught us how to analyze and understand research papers. Overall, it was a great experience and prepared me well for my future as a STEM major.

I learned about the four basic macromolecules of life, DNA replication and gene expression, and some of the key experiments that expanded our knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology.  I also learned how to read and analyze a scientific paper.
I believe my ability to read specific graphics grew and I now have a better understanding of how HIV works.
I learned about lab methods for biochemistry/biophysics and how to interpret data obtained from those methods.
I learned new information about biochemistry and biophysics.
This class was well taught and basic biology concepts were presented in a clear manner.
I obtained a basic understanding of biology. I didn't take AP Bio in high school, so I learned many of the things taught in that class.
Better understanding of the building blocks of life
Experimental design, scientific thinking, and the chemical and physical foundations of biology.

This class taught me a LOT of introductory biology in such a short time, something I realized as I reviewed for the final exam. In addition to biology concepts, I also learned a lot about experimental techniques that put these concepts into practice.
Intro in biochemistry and biophysics
I learned various ways of cell transport, cell communication, as well as how cells inhibit or initiate processes.
I learned more about scientific methods and laboratory tools used in research.

This course really built on the knowledge that I gained during AP Biology in my senior year of high school. It added details to some of the processes we learned about in AP Bio, and I felt like I learned more about these basic biological concepts and processes than in AP Bio because the material was discussed well in this course, while in my AP Bio class, all the material was presented in a confusing and inconsistent way. Through this course, I learned how to apply the knowledge of certain concepts or processes to other problems, including interpreting experimental data and making conclusions based on the biological principles we learned throughout the course.

I learned alot about not only basic biochemistry priniciples, but also how these are applied in the field and in the laboratory. This is a really important introduction into what tools you will use in the lab.

BIOL101 taught a lot of the standard biology knowledge needed to succeed in future biology classes, as well as how to read a scientific paper and apply the information learned in class to a brand new problem. Among the topics covered are the four macromolecules, HIV, and different biochemistry experimental methods.

I developed a basic understanding of biochemistry concepts.  I also learned to think critically about the design of experiments and the interpretation of experimental results, specifically in the context of biochemistry experiments.
A comprehensive knowledge of biochemistry and biophysics, deeper understanding about various research techniques that I actually use in the lab

In this class, you learn a lot about the biology. I learned more about what it means to be a scientist and how biological research is conducted. Overall, I learned a lot of useful information in this course.
Better understanding of biological molecules and processes, with emphasis on experimental procedures.
I was able to transform a very general knowledge of biochem and biophysics into. very in depth understanding.
I deepened my knowledge of DNA replication, translation, transcription, as well as biochemistry and genomics.
Learned about basic biochemistry especially about proteins and DNA transcription/translation.

This course sets up the fundamentals of biochemistry and biophysics that are necessary for going into other areas of biology, and it focuses on lab techniques and the experiments that led to the major discoveries of molecular biology. Given that it is only half a semester, it does not cover material in insane depth, but it does give a solid foundation in molecular biology, and provides a good sense of what the MB&B department is about; in my experience in the intro bio sequence so far, I have gotten the sense that a lot of the series is about providing a taste test of the different biology departments that Yale has to offer. Certainly, BIO101 performed that role.

The knowledge, skills, and insights that I developed taking this course included knowing the introductory basics about biology including that about lipids, carbohydrates, and proteins, as well as learning about experiments that tied in the material we learned very well.
Reading scientific papers, understanding basic biochemistry (membranes, proteins, enzymes), applying scientific knowledge to large concepts (diseases such as HIV)
I gained basic biology knowledge and a solid background for the rest of the intro sequence.
I gained a basic understanding of essential concepts in biology, and strategies to apply them to actual situations.
A working knowledge of basic biology and the scientific process of research and experiment design.

This course was a very good introduction into detailed biological topics. I definitely feel like I have a solidified understanding of basic biological processes such as DNA replication and protein synthesis. The course material was nicely separated into material for baseline understanding, supplemental material for those who need extra help, and additional readings for those who are interested in learning in greater detail.
I learned basic biological processes, how to interact with scientific papers, and how to engage with the subject of biology.
I think I gained a good foundation in biology and the basic mechanisms involved in biological processes.
I learned the basis of many proteins and some basic cellular processes. More prominently, I learned about experimental techniques used commonly in biochemistry.

The course offers a fundamental understanding of the way chemistry explains what happens in living things. The lectures offer just enough material to fully understand the concepts and their implications without becoming too technical.
Felt a greater appreciation for biology and its complexities.
I expanded upon my previous bio background.
I learned many techniques regarding biology.
Basic understanding of biochemistry and biophysics and methods used in biological research.
an introduction to biochemistry and basic biological lab techniques.
Very good introductory Biology and Biochemistry knowledge. Great foundational content.

I learned in extensive detail the many biological processes which make life work. I also began to learn how to read scientific papers despite their difficulty. It was a good overview of biochemistry and biophysics.

I gained knowledge into how biology works on a deeper biophysical level and the aspects of chemistry that tie into biology.

I learned the best method that works for me in studying for biology via Enrichment seminars and study guides provided by the class; I have no doubt that I will be making my own study guides from now on as they are extremely useful.
I learned the fundamentals of biology--lipids, proteins, and DNA. I felt I developed a very strong understanding of how components within the cell interact with each other.
Foundational biology and metabolic processes necessary for success in a variety of jobs.
Reading scientific papers
I learned basic skills regarding biochemistry and biophysics.
Applying key terms and concepts in biology to bigger ideas.
I developed a thorough understanding of biochemistry and molecular biology techniques
I learned how to read scientific papers and how to apply concepts from lecture to new problems on homework assignments and exam/quiz questions.
I learned how to read scientific papers and the basics of biochemistry.
The course reinforced my knowledge in biology and helped me build upon my foundations.
I learned a lot of useful basic bio
I enjoyed how the classes were structured with quizzes and readings every week. They were very helpful learning the material.
I was able to learn more about experimental techniques in biology.
I learned how to analyze data and come up with conclusions.
my knowledge of biology has grown greatly just from taking this course.

Tony Koleske did a great job of introducing the foundational principles of biochemistry, such as the interactions that stabilize proteins, techniques used to analyze proteins, and common experimental setups.
Biology 101 taught and reinforced many of the essential concepts that unruly any molecular understanding of biology. It taught me how to apply this logic to solve and understand biological problems.
I developed the knowledge of learning about certain macromolecules as well as the foundations of biochemistry.
I developed a stronger foundation in biology and reading/analyzing research papers.

This is a great intro course. Prof Koleske is really invested in the material and keeps it exciting throughout all the lectures! I feel like I actually learned a lot about biology and how it is studied in a lab setting and that I would be prepared to work in any lab on campus.
I learned about the structures and functions of the different macromolecules.
I developed an understanding of basic biological concepts
Molecular biology
I learned content very relevant to the field of Biophysics and Biochemistry.

-How to solve basic problems in biology using biochem/physcis
-how basic biological processes work 
-how to read scientific literature

I have a foundational knowledge of biochemistry/biophysicsthis involved a lot of just 'learning the language' by memorizing key terms and processes. I also learned how to read scientific papers, interpret experimental results and plan experimental procedure. So while this course seemed information-driven (e.g. I studied for the final by essentially rewriting all of the lecture slides as flashcards and got an A) I did also learn some essential scientific skills
I learned about many of the fundamental MB&B concepts such as how DNA is transcribed in the cell. I also learned more about HIV and why it is so hard to treat.

I learned about biochemical processes, specifically the synthesis of proteins and DNA/RNA transcription and translation. I also learned about many experiments that led to the discovery of these processes. Finally, I learned how to read a scientific paper.

This course was a refresher for me on the types and characteristics of different macromolecule classes and common laboratory methods. While my high school curriculum prepared me very well for this class, the material had the necessary rigor and introduced a number of vocabulary words I had not come across before.
I did learn many skills pertaining to the subject of this class, but I felt as though the learning process was severely flawed in that I learned much of the material on my own instead of in lecture.
A comprehensive understanding of biochemistrt and biophysics and the current technologies and their uses
I was able to take a thorough and interesting refresher of biology that'll help me in my future career
Besides introductory biology, I was introduced to different experimental techniques and I now know a lot about HIV.
I learned a lot of lab techniques during this course.
HOnestly super insightful into the chemical nature of principle biological functions, made complete sense.
Grasp of foundational bio concepts

I developed the ability to interpret scientific data using the tools I was taught in class. I learned to be on top of my studies, due to the weekly quizzes, and not allow material to slip my mind until the night before the final.
I was kept on track in my studies by reviewing every sunday.
I learned basic intro biology skills and knowledge.
problem solving skills

I gained a more detailed understanding of genetic replication, biological research and experimental methods. I also learned how to interpret charts, gels, and graphs, as well as read scientific papers.
The way 101 was structured incentivized continuous review of the course material. Everything in biology builds on itself.
I learned about how the principles of chemistry and physics fit in with the biology of life.

After taking AP Biology in high school, I, for the most part, knew the content in Biology 101 beforehand. However, the class was still very interesting and I appreciated its focus on specific applications of the concepts. The use of the last few lectures to discuss HIV and its treatments based on the methods we just learned was very effective and made the class worthwhile. I also liked the additional focus on reading scientific literature as a way to introduce the class to the type of papers that we will soon have to read and even write as we take more advanced classes and conduct research.

I learned about the conceptual and experimental aspects of biochemistry and biophysics. For nearly every concept I learned in lecture, I also learned how scientists discovered that concept and continue to study it. I also learned how to read scientific papers.

I learned how DNA is transcribed into RNA and translated into a protein and based on this we have developed connections to other fields such as genomics. Starting from the very basics of what a bond is we were led through a series of lectures that culminated in implementing all the material to explore how HIV works.

Most of what we covered in class was a watered down version of AP Biology that focused way too much on specifics that seemed to be beyond the scope of an intro biology course. There was a huge focus on thermodynamics, for example. I did learn how to read a research paper and about the life cycle of HIV. In terms of skills, I learned how to memorize things and take 10 minute quizzes.
I learned intricacies of biochemistry that clarified many of the concepts to me.
I developed the skill to read scientific papers and fundamental biochemistry knowledge.
I gained a more in-depth knowledge of the basic chemistry involved in biology, and especially some of its applications (gene sequencing, PCR).
I learned the basics of biochemistry from protein function to DNA replication as well as some molecular biology research techniques such as gel electrophoresis and next gen DNA sequence.

I gained a solid grasp on the foundations of biology. I learned a lot about important concepts such as the properties of different macromolecules, the energetics of reactions and metabolic pathways, and how certain enzymes function. I also learned the basis of certain  biotechnologies and methods, such as gel electrophoresis, and applied them to solve problems.
The class is well organized and it's pretty clear from the outset what is being asked of you.
The lecture and the slides were relatively organized. The discussion sections could have been made more difficult. The quizzes could have been better worded. Some of the questions were very bad.
Could make it more worth your while to do the prescribed readings.

A major strength is the professor and the strong communication amongst him, Professor Lin, and all the TAs. A weakness would be the sheer amount of material covered - it did not lend itself to learn but rather memorization.

Strengths: The professor was a great lecturer and was very engaging throughout. The quizzes were geared towards what we learned in lecture and it really forced students to stay on top of the lecture and not fall behind.

One of the strengths of this course is the weekly quizzes which force you to be constantly reviewing the considerable amount of material we cover, so that you aren't cramming everything at the last minute for the final.  The pace was pretty good, and enrichment was helpful, as someone who's never taken AP Bio.  There were a couple instances when material needed for the Wednesday homework was not covered until Monday class which made it difficult to complete in time.

I highly disagree with the structure of how the course is taught in blocks. Biology isnt simply divided into 4 categories that can be taught in isolated blocks that are stacked on top of each other. Instead it should be interwoven for people to learn how biology. Further, I believe there should be more than one biology track like in the chemistry. I didnt l learn anything until lecture 8 or 9 which made it difficult for me to be engaged. I love biology and would have loved to be in a rigorous course that I would have learned a lot in. For someone with no background however this course is great and the learning curve would not be great.

I like how we had weekly quizzes to encourage us to keep up on lecture content, and I like how we were tested more on lecture content than readings because it made showing up to lectures feel necessary. However, I dont think that this was the best course to introduce someone to bio. I already took AP in high school and feel like I didnt learn much new content, except for excessive detail in lab science. The quizzes ere more focused on lab methods and data interpretation than biological concepts, and those quizzes were not graded with much leniency. The course felt more like intro to molecular biology lab than intro to biology, and I feel like it was designed to push students toward doing research rather than just learning biology. The organization of it was good, but the content focus was questionable.
This course is very boring but also moves at an extremely fast pace. There was also too much reading straight from the slides, which made it harder to stay engaged in class.

The professor was very clear and a great lecturer.I also highly enjoyed having section as it cleared up many confusions I had with material presented in class.
 I felt that timing on quizzes was a little short. Additionally, I would prefer if enrichment sections were available to more students or if there could be more peer tutors/ peer tutor hours.

The course was very organized. There was lots of information available and expectations were very clear. Grading was a bit harsh and it would have been nice if things were graded and given back a bit earlier.

There are too many students
Too little time for quizzes

The class was really great in terms of how it developed scientific thinking and critical reasoning. It showed students what it was like to do "real science" in a way most intro courses don't. At the same time, however, there were frequently questions on assessments (quizzes in particular) that felt unfair or poorly written. Frankly, it seemed at times on the quizzes that the professors tried hard to create a challenging quiz to the point where the questions no longer even reflected true understanding of content so much as who can reason the fastest in the 15 minutes allotted per quiz.

Strengths: Although they were a lot of work to prepare for, the weekly quizzes ensured that I kept up with the work in this class and the knowledge learned. Also the professors were very approachable, and Piazza was a great tool for asking questions. Also, I liked that the slides were posted online.
Weaknesses: Sometimes, the lectures just felt very fast, but it was definitely still manageable. Also enrichment seats were limited and you could not drop in for lectures you felt you might need extra help on.

Strength: Professor
Weakness: some odd questions on assessments

It felt like Professor Koleske simply read off the slides which could have been more in-depth in the first place so I wish he would use more colloquial language when explaining the more confusing topics by trying to use slides more as a template for study as opposed to how to teach what the textbook says.
The class is way too big so it is difficult to stay engaged and awake. The discussion sections helped, but it'd be better if class time could made more effective by being smaller.

I definitely think that this course did a good job in discussing all of the material in a clear and simple but accurate way; I only ever felt confused about certain concepts  occasionally throughout the course, but there are so many resources like peer tutors and Piazza that definitely help whenever a student has any questions. I also liked the fact that there were study guides for every lecture that highlighted the key concepts and terms that we should have taken away from each lecture. I also liked the practice problems that were posted for every lecture, because they helped me with knowing the general types of questions that could be asked regarding the material in a particular lecture. One weakness would be the amount of time that it took for us to receive our grades for quizzes and homework. It would always take at least a week to get the grades back, and I thought that it was difficult to gauge whether or not you needed to change your study habits because we wouldn't get the feedback back until after we had already taken the next quiz or submitted the next homework assignment. I think that the teaching fellows should be required to post our homework and quiz grades on canvas by the end of the week after submitting the assignment or taking the quiz, so we can see how we did and we can decide if our study habits and the ways we approach the assignments need to change before we take another quiz or submit another assignment.

Very well organized; study guides that were provided helped a lot, as well as the lecture slides. By the end though, I realized that it actually helped me more not to print out the lecture slides since it allowed me to process more while taking notes on everything rather than just what wasn't in the slides.
strengths was the pace of the course and the context. The weaknesses would be there should be more interaction with the class.

The course was strong in that it provided the resources for people of all different sorts of backgrounds to succeed in the class. For some students who are struggling a bit more or have less of a biology background, Enrichment was helpful for reinforcing information. For those who already took classes like AP Biology in high school, this class served as both a review for the different concepts as well as an extension that goes deeper in a few topics, like HIV. As such, this class doesn't feel too difficult or too boring, regardless of which student takes the class. The use of Piazza also allows the shy students to ask questions at all times, even the night before an assessment, and the TFs and professors always respond at extremely fast rates to help untangle misunderstandings and confusion.

I thought that the course was very well structured. However, when learning research techniques it was hard to learn them from a slide. If introductory biology lab could be made in future years I think it would be beneficial.

This course gives you plenty of resources to understand the material.  There are multiple ways to interact with the material through resources on canvas, but Dr. Lin and the peer tutors are extremely helpful.

Well designed, but too many people. The discussion sections didn't help very much in terms of solidifying understanding of material. Lecture slide info was very well organized. But, quizzes were graded weirdly and often docked off points in unfair ways.

The strength of this course is that there is a lot of help for students that may need extra help understanding the concepts. A weakness is that students come from very different backgrounds in their knowledge of biology so the class may be harder for students who have not taken AP Biology. The the weekly quizzes force you to study the material until you fully grasp the concepts.

A good very basic introduction fo biological concepts. Lectures may feel somewhat long and drawn out if you already have prior knowledge of concepts. Grading on quizzes was not great at times (sometimes looking for key words and phrases in responses rather than understanding of concepts)

The strengths of this course really lie in how great Prof. Koleske was, how interesting and applicable the homework was, and how interesting the material was. I can't think of any specific weaknesses of the course, besides the size, which really can't be helped.
Very well taught class, good slides, great professor, good TAs.
Loved Professor Koleske but I thought that the quizzes were way too difficult. I studied hard and never did well on them--I think that we were underprepared since the course moves so fast.

There is one logistical component of the course that does not make very much sense. I like that the discussion sections are not simply places for review, as they are in many other classes; instead, we dive deeper into the material and take part in interactive activities that are pretty fun. However, the sections that were run as journal clubs were a bit frustrating, because they basically just ran through the correct answers of the homework which was already due that week. I do understand that making that homework due before section ensures that everyone has actually read the paper, but I still think that things could be done a bit better with the journal club sections.

I found the organization of discussion sections to not be the most helpful. I think they can be better facilitated to help us learn the material. The projects take up too much time and limit how much material can be talked about in the discussion section.

I love that the lecture slides are posted ahead of time so that one can print them and take notes on them and I especially like the way that study guides and practice problems are created for quizzes. I would have appreciated more active learning activities in class.

Strengths: Presentation of material, appropriateness of quizzes and homework, abundance of resources
Weaknesses: Material sometimes presented too quickly

It can be difficult if you did not take AP Bio, but Prof. Lin and Prof. Koleske do a good job of offering additional resources. I think that the policy for enrichment should be changed since I don't think it makes sense to kick a student who is doing well out of the section. It means that enrichment is actually working for them!

The course was taught at a great pace so that those who had never covered the material could understand but also so that students who had taken AP biology or other advanced biology courses before could stay engaged. Any improvements might be in discussion sections. They seemed somewhat superficial and I think more detail could have been covered through those small groups. While in understand there is a level of depth the class is limited to logistically, I did not like that a common response to many questions was, "that is out of the scope of Biology 101."
The course was very fast paced.

I definitely think the Enrichment sessions were very helpful. It was a great way to review concepts I was struggling with. I also really liked the study guides for each lecture, because it highlighted all the important information that I needed to know. An improvement I would suggest is a quicker turnaround time for releasing quiz scores/answer keys. It was difficult to know if you had to change your study habits/what you were struggling with when it took so long for us to get our work back. I thought the questions on the final were a bit nuanced, and I think that was unhelpful in testing how much of the material I knew.

The course was very fair in terms of quizzes and exams. All material was on the lecture and the questions were a nice balance between memorization and application. The lecture was a bit disinteresting, as only the content of the lecture slides was discussed.

It would have helped to have more practice questions that would test your understandings of the materials. What the professors want is to be able to use and apply knowledge, and it would have helped to get more practice in that.

I think that the homework and quizzes were difficult because the lectures did not go into depth about the topics and we were expected to know more in order to complete assignments. I think that we glossed over lots of complex topics in lecture, making the class confusing and hard to follow.

Felt like almost everything in the course was a strength. Only negative is that we got back feedback in the form of grades fairly late, ie the first graded quiz was handed back several days after we had already taken the second one, etc.
I think this course was great! The lectures explained exactly what I needed to know, sections and homeworks reinforced what we learned in lectures, and the quizzes and exams were fair assessments.
A huge weakness of the class is that it is targeted at students with widely varying backgrounds in biology. For some people, it's quite difficult, while for others, it's a complete waste of time.
Strengths were professor and Prof. Lin. Weaknesses were the weekly quizzes that were very stressful.
The strengths of this course was it was very application based in which we interpreted experiments and applied relevant concepts.

The course is very well organized and I never felt lost. I think the work load was manageable and relevant to what we were learning. I think the lectures were always interesting though in the beginning it wasnt very challenging because it felt very repetitive of ap bio.

I think the weakness of this course is just that it is very large and hard to get a good one-on-one interaction with the teaching staff. While I was lucky enough to be in Enrichment and have a stellar TF for my section, this cannot possibly be the case for all students.

The strengths of this course lie in the teaching staff, however. They are extremely knowledgable in their fields, in particular Professor Koleske. It was humbling to be able to study under him as he would present a random polymerase and off-handedly mention his role in discovering said polymerase.

Sections at times seemed quite unengaging. The exercises were useful in emphasizing simple concepts. However, I thought that much of section focused on the easier concepts presented in class. I would have personally benefited from a more thorough review of the more complex topics in class (such as DNA sequencing). Perhaps section can also devote time towards emphasizing concepts from lecture.

Assessments are conceptual understanding based, but I found myself struggling despite understanding concepts. There should be a way to apply conceptual knowledge, and this isnt common knowledge, perhaps the course would benefit by trying to teach this as well.

Although I wasn't thrilled to have a quiz every week at the beginning of the course, I realized that they were extremely helpful by the end. After reviewing the material for the quizzes each week, I felt much more prepared for the final than I have in other classes. I wish Bio 102 had the same structure.
Discussion section is run like a class. Should be run as a platform for questions.

Strengths = structure
Weaknesses = Quizzes could be overly difficult at times
Overall, the course is well structured and organized.
It's a large lecture, which makes it a weakness, because I didn't feel like we thoroughly covered the confusing concepts in class.
The questions were very explicit and we knew exactly what we were expected to learn. Thanks!

Strengths are that the course is well-organized and discussion sections were well-taught. Weaknesses are that lectures were sometimes taught too fast when most of the class didn't understand a concept.
The course was helpful for brushing up on my high school knowledge of biology.
Class is done way too quickly for anyone with small misunderstandings to recover
Professor Koleske was amazing.  He shouldn't change a think.  However, section is useless and should be dedicated to asking questions or eliminated.
I loved this class! I do wish that there was more focus in discussion sections on the material we learned in class and not just on the papers.
I felt that it was too slow for many people.

Strengths:
Very organized
Weaknesses:
Not a lot of time to really learn the material
The processor was very engaging and easy to understand.

The course did a good job of providing resources for students with questions, but as a student who took AP Bio, it didn't always feel like I was learning something new. That said, the course did a pretty job job of reinforcing concepts and ensuring that students had a solid foundation in biochemistry.
My strengths in the course were understanding the concepts well and applying it to problems. My weakness was concisely eroding and communicating my answers.

Strengths of the course is the Koleske is a great lecturer and that he keeps the lectures engaging. Weaknesses of the course is the fact that the quiz grades so heavily weigh down your grade that messing up more than one can absolutely destroy your average. So proceed with caution. But! One good thing about this course is that you can drop the lowest graded assignment in each category (homework, attendance to section, and quizzes) which is definitely nice.

I really liked that we had section considering the large size of lecture. I liked that the pre-class quizzes forced us to do the reading and understand the material but I often felt rushed and sometimes felt I couldnt show how I knew the material because of the time constraints.
The lectures were good and so were the sections. The quizzes were hard at times, but they forced you to study and keep up with the subject matter, which made studying for the final a lot easier.
I believe Professor Koleske did a great job keeping the course engaging and interesting. The enrichment sessions offered helped immensely.

The manner in which Professor koleske presented the information was most definitely a strength. He was increasingly engaging and clear. That being said, I felt that course jumped around subject-wise and could be better organized in terms of the depths of what we learned.

This course is very well-organized and is structured to provide a lot of support and practice to enhance student learning. The lectures are very interesting, but could perhaps be made more engaging with a few more activities.

Strengths: 
-extremely well organized
-Koleske is clear, concise, eloquent
-exposure to primary scientific literature
-very reasonable workload
-types of test questions


Weaknesses: 
-quizzes very fast paced

I have mixed feelings about the quizzes. I appreciated how they forced us to consistently actively engage with the class materialI  consider this a course strength because it promotes rich learninghowever, the time pressure made it hard to do them to the best of my ability and as a result I do not think they reflect my learning well. I think either giving more time or making them shorter could maintain the benefits these bring to the class.

I think a strength is how we engage with a few scientific papers and spend homework assignments and section going over them, that was a cool part of the course. Another strength is the use of Piazza, that was really helpful and felt like an organic part of the course.

The strengths include the fact that there are resources to seek help such as Prof. Lin's enrichment sections and the peer tutors. Additionally, the material overall was very interesting.

A weakness which affect me is that the course moves very fast, especially for someone who has little biology background such as myself.

The strengths of this course were Professor Koleske's dynamic lecture style and the ability to engage in active learning during section. The course's weaknesses were the impersonality of the large lecture, which naturally comes with it being a big course, but I think more discussion among peers during lecture would improve the course.

Less of reading slides verbatim, more focused on elaborating on topics and actually testing fairly on these elaborations. Make sure students understand and promote questions about content instead of just taking topics further right after learning them.
Very well organized. Teaching was in an engaging manner.

strengths - great professor
weaknesses - quizzes did not help
The discussion sections and homework are fantastic, no weaknesses
VERY organized,  pretty well taught, pretty engaging, good job not just making it memorization

The sections are a strength of the course. I loved the section format. Working in groups and problem solving, while applying the knowledge we learned in lecture worked really well. I think the weakly quizzes were both a strength and weakness. While I feel like I was more prepared for the final because of the quizzes, I also think the lag time between receiving graded quizzes and taking another one was too long. I would like to take the next quiz after having realized my mistakes from the prior quiz.
The powerpoints and enrichment  were amazing . They were detailed and helped when reviewing.
The professor was engaging and explained concepts well. Content was interesting. Discussion sections were engaging.
Very good and well organized

Strengths: plenty of resources (piazza, peer tutors, TF's, office hours, etc.) and engaging professor

Weaknesses: TF during discussion section simply ran through slides without much engagement/detailed explanation.
Lecture was good, but very confusing at times. The readings were overwhelming.

I really liked the way this course was arranged because all the materials constantly connected to each other, this made absorbing the large amount of information much easier. I feel like i have a really solid understanding of biochem.
The strength of this course was presenting the material in many different engaging ways, to ensure that every students had an equal opportunity to learn.

The biggest strengths of Biology 101 were its professors. Professor Koleske was a very engaging and interesting lecturer, even when some of the content being taught was relatively basic. He made sure to circle the concepts back to practical applications at all available moments, which was very effective. Likewise, Professor Lin was very receptive and helpful in answering questions.

The class just had a few weaknesses that can be improved upon with small fixes. First, the seemingly keyword-based grading system occasionally led to grading that did not actually reflect the content of answers. Just for example, I lost a point on a quiz after using the word "hydrophobic" in my answer several times, but did not use the specific phrase "hydrophobic interactions." Of course, this is not at all a huge deal, but it can be discouraging to lose points more often on technicalities than for the sake of learning the correct answers. The only other shortcoming I felt in this class was having to attend mandatory discussion sections. Of course, I appreciate having the option of going to a section to learn more, but the sections in Biology 101 were a bit drawn out and simplified so that they were useful to some students but less so for others. Making these optional, in my opinion, would be equally as effective.

The lecture was extremely engaging, and it was incredibly helpful to have the opportunity to print out the lecture slides beforehand. The course is well-organized and does a great job teaching the concepts and then making sure students can then apply those concepts. The additional files and study guides were also very helpful. I think the Monday quizzes would be more effective if they were done outside of class. I would study hard for those quizzes but always had trouble with the application questions. I think take-home quizzes would still force us to learn the material and to apply it but would be better for grades.

One of the biggest strengths of the course is the enrichment offer that is offered to underprepared students for biology. At the same time the fact that the course assumes preparation in biology is one of its greatest weaknesses. Unfortunately, Yale is not the place it was before. With the inclusion of low income students, there comes the need to better adapt classes for students whose preparation is not remotely close to that of high income students who come from private schools. I think it would be extremely beneficial if enrichment was offered more than once a week.

The strength of this course is that there are many opportunities to work towards the grade you want. I really like the style of having multiple graded things due each week: a quiz and a homework. Multiple quizzes instead of two huge tests. This is the best way to decrease stress in a class. Also the ability to drop your lowest grade from each grading category was very helpful in making biology 101 a learning experience rather than a weed out experience. However, I am not saying that this class is not a weed out. It certainly is. The way that they water down everything. For example they would say "certain chemical group" instead of functional group as we have all learned it. It almost seems intentional the way they oversimplify concepts to confuse us and mess with how we learned it in the past. The quizzes are way too stressful, and they rely on memorization. There are pointless questions on exams that are clearly meant to create a distribution within the class to "get" people and make sure that not everybody is getting that 100. I can't complain because I figured out this course early on. As in, I figured out that it was a weed out class, so I did pretty well.
It is very well structured, the quizzes were slightly bothersome in weight vs. material tested.
It is very well structured.

I enjoyed the inclusion of applications of the content in lectures, including explanations of techniques such as PCR and how they worked. I did not gain much from section, and did not find the activities we did during section to be helpful.

This course does a very good job of going through the basics of biochemistry. The weekly quizzes were bothersome at times but they did keep me on top of the material. In section, the activities were often neither interesting nor particularly challenging.

In terms of strengths, I found that the course content was understandable, that the exams mirrored the lecture topics well, and that that the homework assignments were interesting but manageable. In terms of weaknesses, I thought the textbook readings did not seem to help or hinder my understanding of the content. I would suggest that lectures link concepts to the previous nights' readings so that there is a stronger benefit for the readings in the course.
I wouldn't recommend it as a class just for fun/interest, but if it's being taken as a major requirement it's perfectly fine.
If you want to learn bio, this course will get the job done.
Its a fantastic exploration of introductory biology, I would recommend.
I would totally recommend this course to another STEM/pre-med student. It is definitely not a gut STEM class, but as a STEM major, I really enjoyed the class a lot.

This course is a prerequisite for most biology and science majors, so you will most likely have to take it unless you place out of it.  Having shopped the fall sequence and enrolled in the spring sequence, I strongly recommend waiting until the spring to start.  I found the pace to be more manageable, the content more understandable, and was generally more prepared to do well after completing a semester of college already.

I would not recommend this class to anyone that it is not required for their major and if they have a strong background. But this is a good introduction for people that need bio and havent taken much bio in high school
I would only recommend this as a prerequisite course, not to actually learn some interesting biological concepts.
No this is a class that you should not take unless you have too for a major or pre-med requirements.
I would recommend this course because it provides a strong basis for understanding basic biological concepts.
It's a good class, and very manageable even if you're not a STEM major.
Yes. The quizzes can be a bit scarring, but Professor Koleske really cares about his students and is a phenomenal person!

Yes, especially since this is a required introductory course for the biology majors. In particular, I felt that the Biol 101 course was a good transition to biology at the college-level and was well-organized. There are lots of resources you can use to prepare for assessments.
Yes great intro
Yes, people need this class but make sure you are actively engaged because it is easy to zone out for a second and when you come back be very lost. Also, ask questions!!
I would highly recommend this course to premed and students who are interested in majoring in Biology.
Take this class if it's required for your major. I think it is too big to be taken for fun.

I would recommend this course because you learn a lot of interesting things about basic and fundamental biological processes, and you get to apply these concepts to real-life scenarios like how the general processes in our bodies work, experiments and data, and HIV/AIDS. There isn't that much work for this course, so it's a nice class to take if you're interested in biology or if you want a somewhat challenging but also relaxed science class. Granted, this is my take on the class because I had a relatively strong biology background before starting the class, and I know that many people don't have much of a high school biology background, so this class may be more challenging if you have a weak foundation in biology.
Yes, since you have to most of the science majors.

I would recommend this class to another student because it does go deeper than the high school biology course and you learn quite a bit in the class with the quizzes which help reinforce learning each week. The sections are also helpful because they allow you to look at a related problem in the same topic and think about the information in a new way.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who wants to understand basic biology and basic reasoning for biology experiments.  I think this would be useful to both STEM and non-STEM students.
Yes, but not if non-STEM  or non-premed

Yes I would recommend this course. Most people take this course if they need it for their major and most of the students in the class are premed. I think that the course was well taught and helps students learn a lot about biology.
Yes, I would recommend that people take this class. I did not get an enormous amount out of it because of my previous knowledge, but I know that many people learned a ton.

Absolutely. Though you have to take this class if you're planning on being an MCDB, MBB, EEB major, or pre-med, and I do fall under the category of people who needed to take it as a prereq, I really enjoyed this course.
Good class, would recommend, Koleske is a great professor.
I found this class very interesting. I recommend if your interested in a field that is related to biochemistry/biology in general.
I would recommend students only take this course if they have to. Unless a person feels that they really excel in Biology, I recommend taking it Credit/D if you just want to take it for fun.
I would recommend this course to a student with a strong interest in the fundamentals of biology or to a Pre-Medical/biology student.
I would recommend the course to any student interested in science.
I would recommend this course.  It is a fantastic introductory science course, and though it is fast paced, it is manageable.
I would definitely recommend this course. I always found myself interested in learning more about biology after every lecture. The material was useful and was often connected to modern issues.
Most students taking this class are doing it because of pre-reqs. However, it is not bad at all.
Yes, but if you aren't confident in biology be sure to sign up for Enrichment.
Yes, if you plan to pursue any biology based labwork.

I would recommend this course to all students at Yale; I gained a fundamental understanding of the chemical mechanisms of organisms which are extremely relevant to the society today. It is organized well and I felt the professors' demand in us was very well thought-out and reasonable to stimulate learning and mastery.
I took this course for a pre med prerequisite, but otherwise I don't see the point in taking it unless you have to.
Yes, great all around course, and not really too difficult.
The professor is amazing and the class was very well taught.
If you have to take it, or if you have no background in biology yet you're interested in learning a bit, then sure. Otherwise, there are more interesting "intro" biology/science courses out there.
Yes. It was a good intro course.
Yes I would recommend as a good intro bio class.
Yes, it is a necessary prerequisite but also was engaging.
Yes instructor Koleske is also very good.
Yes, I would recommend this to any student interested in biology
Yes! It is a great BIOL 101 course. I do not know how it compares to the Fall term BIOL 101 offered, but I really liked Koleske's teaching style and learned a lot from the class.
I would recommend this course! I found lectures very engaging and interesting. Piazza was also very useful, homework and textbook reading were straightforward, and testing was fair.
Yes! Important intro to bio sequence.
Take it, its not bad and Professor Koleske is a good lecturer
Yes, 100%. I knew nearly nothing going in, and I appreciated Bio101 for helping me get a good foundation.
Would definitely recommend, especially with professor Koleske!
I would recommend this course to people who seek to improve their critical thinking skills and their abilities to apply concepts to problem-solving situations.
I would!
Yes. The course was helpful in understanding more about biology.
Not particularly.  I feel this course focused too much on the specifics and not enough on underlying principles, which I feel is inappropriate as an introductory course, and just unnecessary.
I would, not a premed weeder bio course it really is pretty interesting
Yes!!
Yes
I would recommend if you have to take it, but if you have taken AP biology, you're probably very well prepared and the course will be a breeze.
If they need it, take it. Its not that bad.
This is a great course to take to learn a lot of material in a short amount of time. Not only do you learn an immense amount of information but you also master it.
Yes; it isn't always the most exciting course, but it certainly is helpful (especially for bio majors or other pre-med candidates).
Yes, I'm biased because I love biology, but I think biochemistry and biophysics are fascinating. Koleske did an amazing job making the class engaging and interesting.
I would recommend this course to a student wither if they have an interest in biology or if they are going to have to take the BIO sequence for a major requirement.
This a pretty good intro course for bio but it was unfortunate that many people who already have strong foundations in bio were taking the same course as though who didnt.

Yes, I would recommend this class. It is very well organized and interesting all the way through. Although the weekly quizzes can seem stressful at first, when the final came I felt really prepared since I had already studied all the material.
Yes, I liked it.
Yes. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

I've heard varying things about the bio modules depending on when you take them, but I had a wonderful time learning from Professor Koleske and Professor Lin. They were always conscientious of how the students were doing, and continued to make clear efforts to keep the class light and enjoyable despite the hefty amount of material being covered.
It's required, so yes.

I would recommend this course to another student. A lot of students take it because it is a requirement for their major or to take upper level courses, but it is also a very interesting introductory course on its own.
Yes, but only if genuinely interested in biology or need to fulfill prereq.

It's a requirement for many majors and premed, and it can be engaging and rewarding if you get past past the annoyance of all of the memorization. The material was interesting, I really enjoyed applying our knowledge to exploring HIV/AIDS at the ending, and this is one of those courses that you can get as much from as you put in. So yes, if you have to take it or are interested in biology
Yes, I would recommend this course as there is a lot of interesting biology material covered in this course, albeit a little quickly.

While I am sure that many take this course to satisfy their major or pre-med requirements, it is actually a very engaging course. Professor Koleske teaches lectures in a way that is interesting and makes the material easy to learn. I would recommend this course not only for people interested going into a field related to biology, but also for anyone genuinely interested in the subject.
It was a very solid intro to biochemistry. Anyone in need of an SC where they actually learn something would benefit from this class.
Yes; it is a great introduciton to bio concepts
Yes, I absolutely would recommend this course to any students interested in science and its relation to life.
Yes, especially for those going into the science field.
Definitely, super interesting and important intro to biology.
Yea
This is a pretty standard intro course. It was effective in teaching the basic material.
Yes
Yes I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in/wants to learn intro biology skills
yes, helps you to learn how to apply what you have learned in biology in a real-life setting.
Yes! It is a terrific introductory science course. The abundant resources make the course manageable for individuals with any level of past science experience.
Take it if you need to. I don't think I would recommend this class to someone looking for a science credit.
Absolutely. Professor Koleske was hilarious and passionate which made the class experience thoroughly enjoyable.

I would recommend this course because it is a requirement for so many of Yale's science majors. However, after the placement test, I could have placed out of Biology 101, but I still took the course. If I could go back and change my choice, I would probably skip the class and take a more advanced course. For what it was worth, nevertheless, the professors were effective and the content was taught clearly in a practical manner.
It is a great introductory class for anyone. Its concepts are fascinating, and you don't need to be a science major or pre-med to appreciate the material. The lectures are engaging and interesting.

Assuming that the student has a reasonable preparation in biology I would recommend the course to another student. If not I'd recommend familiarizing oneself with basic concepts at least before considering taking the course.

This class is not something that you "recommend" to other students because it is a pre-med requirement and it seems as if everybody in that class is a pre-med. I would take it because it is required for many majors and medical school.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in Biology.
Yes, it is not your traditional intro bio course.

I found it mainly worthwhile simply because it is a prerequisite for further courses. I generally do not learn well in large lectures so I had very low expectations for this course. Overall I found the course to be fulfilling, but I do not hold it up to the same standards in which I regard the seminars I have taken at Yale.

I would recommend this course to another student. The course is understandable for people with any level of background in biology. The course content is immensely practical if you plan on trying your hand at biological research as an undergraduate. The lectures are easy to follow and it easy to access help when you feel stuck.
